instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The team at Secureworks analyzed artifacts from March 2022 that were uploaded to VirusTotal. Analyzing prior updates against the current version of REvil Ransomware, the CTU’s assessment is that the malware was modified by the group that has access to the source code, Gold Southfield. Several new modifications to the REvil ransomware are detailed in the Secureworks report. The newer version of REvil uses bcrypt to modify hash values so that researchers cannot identify affiliates who utilize this malware. The newest sample of REvil also removed the code that would indicate that it is being used from a “prohibited region”. Additionally, the updated version of REvil delivers a ransom note with newly identified TOR domains.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: REvil Development Indicates Reemergence of Gold Southfield

parsed_raw_data.title: REvil Development Indicates Reemergence of Gold Southfield
parsed_raw_data.overview: The team at Secureworks analyzed artifacts from March 2022 that were uploaded to VirusTotal. Analyzing prior updates against the current version of REvil Ransomware, the CTU’s assessment is that the malware was modified by the group that has access to the source code, Gold Southfield. Several new modifications to the REvil ransomware are detailed in the Secureworks report. The newer version of REvil uses bcrypt to modify hash values so that researchers cannot identify affiliates who utilize this malware. The newest sample of REvil also removed the code that would indicate that it is being used from a “prohibited region”. Additionally, the updated version of REvil delivers a ransom note with newly identified TOR domains.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The Android malware named Oscorp which surfaced in early 2021 was a banking Trojan that used a combination of phishing kits and vishing calls to achieve its objective. According to a report from Cleafy, it has evolved to target the users of an extensive list of financial institutions in a number of geographies. It also targets cryptocurrency apps. Its feature set now includes the ability to make calls, send, intercept, and delete SMS messages, log keystrokes, conduct overlay attacks on 150+ apps, and provide its operators remote access via VNC using the WebRTC protocol and Android Accessibility Services. Recently, a new Android botnet named UBEL which uses the Oscorp codebase was observed. This may be a fork of Oscorp, it may also be a simple rebranding by one of the multiple threat actors using the Oscorp codebase.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Android Malware - Oscorp and UBEL

parsed_raw_data.title: Android Malware - Oscorp and UBEL
parsed_raw_data.overview: The Android malware named Oscorp which surfaced in early 2021 was a banking Trojan that used a combination of phishing kits and vishing calls to achieve its objective. According to a report from Cleafy, it has evolved to target the users of an extensive list of financial institutions in a number of geographies. It also targets cryptocurrency apps. Its feature set now includes the ability to make calls, send, intercept, and delete SMS messages, log keystrokes, conduct overlay attacks on 150+ apps, and provide its operators remote access via VNC using the WebRTC protocol and Android Accessibility Services. Recently, a new Android botnet named UBEL which uses the Oscorp codebase was observed. This may be a fork of Oscorp, it may also be a simple rebranding by one of the multiple threat actors using the Oscorp codebase.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Kaspersky published a blog post detailing three malware families exploiting XMRig miner for monetary gain. The first malware family discussed is dubbed "ransominer" due to its combined use of ransomware and crypto-mining. The infection chain involves a common Trojan installed on a victim's machine with the purpose of installing administration programs, adding a new user, and opening RDP access. A ransomware payload is then executed, followed by the XMRig loader; at the same time the user is seeing the ransom note while Monero mining is being performed in the background. The second family discussed is the Prometei backdoor. After a few years in operation, it expanded its capabilities by also distributing XMRig. After brute-forcing MS SQL credentials and gaining access, PowerShell scripts are run and privileges are elevated. Purple Fox and Prometei are both installed on the host. Lastly, the XMRig miner is downloaded from the C2 server and executed. The third family is the Cliptomaner miner. This malware is similar to the other families but has the added functionality of replacing crypto-wallet addresses in the clipboard. Additionally, instead of being written in a compiled language, it is fully written in AutoIT.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Malware Leveraging XMRig Miner

parsed_raw_data.title: Malware Leveraging XMRig Miner
parsed_raw_data.overview: Kaspersky published a blog post detailing three malware families exploiting XMRig miner for monetary gain. The first malware family discussed is dubbed "ransominer" due to its combined use of ransomware and crypto-mining. The infection chain involves a common Trojan installed on a victim's machine with the purpose of installing administration programs, adding a new user, and opening RDP access. A ransomware payload is then executed, followed by the XMRig loader; at the same time the user is seeing the ransom note while Monero mining is being performed in the background. The second family discussed is the Prometei backdoor. After a few years in operation, it expanded its capabilities by also distributing XMRig. After brute-forcing MS SQL credentials and gaining access, PowerShell scripts are run and privileges are elevated. Purple Fox and Prometei are both installed on the host. Lastly, the XMRig miner is downloaded from the C2 server and executed. The third family is the Cliptomaner miner. This malware is similar to the other families but has the added functionality of replacing crypto-wallet addresses in the clipboard. Additionally, instead of being written in a compiled language, it is fully written in AutoIT.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has reported on their observations of threats facing the retail industry as the sector grows. With so many opportunities to siphon off transactions, retail remains a lucrative target for cybercriminals. According to the 2020 IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence Index, the retail services industry is the second most-attacked of all industries. Cybersecurity professionals focused on this sector have pointed to two particular security threats that top the list of attacks types: automated account takeover and business email compromise. Additionally, some firms are advocating the use of active defense deception—the use of decoy data— to protect their most sensitive data. In their report, the researchers also highlight the key threat actors targeting this industry.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Retail Sector: 2020 Top Threats

instruction: Write the mitre mitigations related to Malicious Android Apps Stealing Credentials
output:
Sure. Here are the related mitre mitigations: Mitigation ID: M1005
Mitigation name and Description: Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1006
Mitigation name and Description: Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1011
Mitigation name and Description: User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1012
Mitigation name and Description: Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1032
Mitigation name and Description: Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A campaign distributing credential stealers has been observed by researchers from Trend Micro since mid-December 2020. Infection is accomplished via multi-stage processes beginning with a malicious Excel file. The file contains an AHK script compiler executable, a malicious AHK script file, and a VBA AutoOpen macro. The malware communicates with C2 servers in the U.S., the Netherlands, and Sweden and specifically targets U.S. and Canadian customers. The compiler is a legitimate application and is used to compile and execute an AHK script. The script is used for persistence, profiling victims, and downloading and executing the AHK script on a victim system. The downloader creates an auto-run link for the executable in the startup folder. The script then profiles victims by generating a unique ID based on the serial number of the C drive. An HTTP GET request is sent every five seconds and is used to serve as the request path to the C2 server as well as retrieve and execute the AHK script on the infected machine. Other AHK scripts can be employed against the victim depending on information obtained by the initial script. At present, the only commands seen have been 'deletecookies' and 'passwords'. The stealer portion is written in AHK and harvests credentials from browsers, then exports those credentials to the attacker. Instructions within are written in Russian on usage of the script. Browsers scanned include Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Opera, Firefox, and Internet Explorer.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: US and Canadian Bank Customers Targeted by Credential Stealer

The malware communicates with C2 servers in the U.S., the Netherlands, and Sweden and specifically targets U.S. and Canadian customers. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A compromised administrator account with high-level privileges led to the discovery of a Nefilim ransomware attacker's movements prior to launching the attack. The attacker had gained access approximately one month prior to the attack and spent that time stealing other credentials to include the domain administrator account. Ultimately, the attacker was able to make off with hundreds of GB of data. The initial infection vector was a vulnerable version of Citrix. In a sad twist, the account that was compromised was that of an employee who'd passed away months prior to the attack. The account was active due to the use of services belonging to that account. The attack mostly occurred in the middle of the night thus leading researchers to determine the movements and commands issued from the account were from a nefarious source. The attacker was able to use the access gained to create a new account which was assigned to the domain admin group. Since there were no alarms set to notify administrators of a new account creation, the account went unnoticed until the ransomware attack had been carried out. The attacker was able to delete 150 virtual servers and used Microsoft's BitLocker to encrypt server backups. At the time of the attack, the company's Citrix Storefront 7.15 CU3 was vulnerable to 1 critical and 4 high rated CVE vulnerabilities. Those vulnerabilities have since been patched.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Nefilim Using Ghost Credentials

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The Andariel APT group has been conducting a campaign targeting South Korean entities in the construction, home network service, manufacturing, and media sectors. Kasperksy mentions two infection vectors in their report, one being the use of weaponized Word documents. The second is less clear in that the vector could be either a malicious version of a PDF reader or a weaponized PDF. In both cases, a second-stage payload is delivered to the victim. The second stage payload communicates with the campaign's C&C servers. A third stage payload is delivered to selected victims, and in one case, custom-built ransomware was also installed. Kaspersky notes that Andariel has evolved its TTPs and the intention of this campaign was to deliver ransomware.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Andariel Campaign Targeting South Korea Includes Ransomware

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A Chinese-speaking actor using large-scale campaigns across South East Asia since October 2020, has been named LuminousMoth by Kaspersky. The great majority of victims are in the Philippines with Myanmar being the second most affected country. The actual targets of the campaign are likely government entities. In its report, Kaspersky notes two infection vectors. An email sent to victims contains a Dropbox link which leads to an RAR archive. To disguise the archive as a Word document, the “file_subpath” parameter is set to that of a file with a DOCX extension. Inside the archive were two malicious DLLs along with two legitimate executables files which were used to sideload the DLLs. If the first stage is successful, the second stage consists of installing a Cobalt Strike beacon and achieving persistence using a registry entry. The report notes that in the Philippines, there may have been another infection vector involved. The malware attempts to spread itself by copying malicious files to removable storage devices. In some cases, on systems located in Myanmar, an information stealer impersonated the Zoom video-conferencing application. It scanned the infected systems for files with specific extensions and exfiltrated those found to its C&C server. On some other systems, a tool to steal cookies from the Chrome web browser was deployed. Kaspersky notes a number of similarities in LuminousMoth's TTPs and targeting with another group named HoneyMyte (aka Mustang Panda), and finds with medium to high confidence that the LuminousMoth activity is connected to HoneyMyte.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: LuminousMoth APT Group Targeting South Asia

Inside the archive were two malicious DLLs along with two legitimate executables files which were used to sideload the DLLs. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Proofpoint researchers have identified a new threat group that they refer to as TA2721. The group is using Spanish language emails to spread the Bandook malware. An earlier ESET report noted the malware in a campaign they named Bandidos. The Proofpoint report notes that TA2721 campaigns are low in the volume of emails, typically less than 300 per campaign, and target employees with Spanish-language surnames in less than 100 companies, at a time. The emails have a PDF file attached which contains a link to a password-protected RAR archive. The password is provided in the PDF. The archive contains an executable file which is the Bandook payload. Proofpoint has located two variants of Bandook used in the campaigns. Bandook achieves persistence through a Registry run key. C&C communications are encrypted using AES in CFB mode, a hardcoded key, and an initialization vector that differs from the publicly available versions of Bandook.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Bandook Malware in Spanish Language Emails

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Since the beginning of 2021, 360Netlab has detected three new versions of the Necro botnet. Necro is also known as Python.IRCBot, and N3Cr0m0rPh. The three new versions incorporate a host of new features including propagation using weak Telnet passwords and a 1-day vulnerability (CVE-2020-35665) in TerraMaster TOS, exploitation of some n-day vulnerabilities, increased use of code obfuscation, a domain generation algorithm (DGA) for C&C server domain names, and payloads distributed as both Python scripts and ELF binaries. The compiled ELF binary is used in situations where the infected host does not provide Python 2 due to its EOL status. The exploit for TerraMaster TOS was introduced into the Necro code eight days are the vulnerability was made public. Other payloads downloaded include the xmrig and xmrig1 cryptominers. The same actors are believed to be behind all three of the new versions, and the download servers used for Necro have also been observed hosting Mirai variants and malicious Windows executables.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: New Versions of the Necro Botnet in the Wild

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Cisco Talos has discovered a campaign that is targeting Indian government personnel. The campaign has been named Operation Armor Piercer and began around December 2020. The campaign themes are typically related to Indian government guides and operational documents. The campaign mainly uses emails with attached malicious documents, however, in some cases the attachments are archive files. In either case, they provide a loader that is used to download the final payload, usually from a fake domain or compromised website. The payloads are usually commodity RATs, either Ave Maria (aka WarzoneRAT) or the NetwireRAT. The RATS are largely unmodified with the exception of the Armor Piercer C&C configuration details. The campaign exhibits similarities in the TTPs used to other known groups including Mythic Leopard, SideCopy, and Transparent Tribe.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Operation Armor Piercer

parsed_raw_data.title: Operation Armor Piercer
parsed_raw_data.overview: Cisco Talos has discovered a campaign that is targeting Indian government personnel. The campaign has been named Operation Armor Piercer and began around December 2020. The campaign themes are typically related to Indian government guides and operational documents. The campaign mainly uses emails with attached malicious documents, however, in some cases the attachments are archive files. In either case, they provide a loader that is used to download the final payload, usually from a fake domain or compromised website. The payloads are usually commodity RATs, either Ave Maria (aka WarzoneRAT) or the NetwireRAT. The RATS are largely unmodified with the exception of the Armor Piercer C&C configuration details. The campaign exhibits similarities in the TTPs used to other known groups including Mythic Leopard, SideCopy, and Transparent Tribe.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing an exploit chain involving multiple Chrome and Windows 0-days to deliver malware. The exploit chain was observed being used in highly targeted attacks against multiple companies. It began with a Chrome remote code execution exploit. While the exploit code itself was unable to be retrieved, the time frame of the attack leads the researchers to believe CVE-2021-21224 was exploited. The next stage in the exploit chain uses two Windows vulnerabilities: an information disclosure vulnerability, CVE-2021-31955, and a buffer overflow vulnerability, CVE-2021-31956. In combination, these vulnerabilities can allow the attacker to carry out a privilege escalation exploit, ultimately using the access to inject malware into a system process. In terms of the malware used, a stager is used to download a dropper which, in turn, installs two executables. The first executable is a service that is used as a launcher for the second, a remote shell. From the remote shell, the attacker can upload and download files, create processes, sleep, or self-delete. Kaspersky was unable to attribute this activity to a known threat actor and has dubbed the actor behind this campaign "PuzzleMaker.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: PuzzleMaker Attacks with Chrome Zero-Day Exploit Chain

parsed_raw_data.title: PuzzleMaker Attacks with Chrome Zero-Day Exploit Chain

The next stage in the exploit chain uses two Windows vulnerabilities: an information disclosure vulnerability, CVE-2021-31955, and a buffer overflow vulnerability, CVE-2021-31956. In combination, these vulnerabilities can allow the attacker to carry out a privilege escalation exploit, ultimately using the access to inject malware into a system process. In terms of the malware used, a stager is used to download a dropper which, in turn, installs two executables. The first executable is a service that is used as a launcher for the second, a remote shell. From the remote shell, the attacker can upload and download files, create processes, sleep, or self-delete. Kaspersky was unable to attribute this activity to a known threat actor and has dubbed the actor behind this campaign "PuzzleMaker.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign that is leveraging OneDrive to host their malicious content. The phishing email claims a file has been shared via OneDrive and provides a shortened OneDrive link to visit. Hosted on this OneDrive URL is a PDF containing hyperlinked text to a second-stage phishing page. If a user falls for this trick and visits the secondary page, they are presented with logon options for multiple email services combined with further OneDrive branding. Each login option provides a different fake login page; for example, one led to an Outlook login page while another presented a Box login. When a user provides credentials, the entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to a benign research article.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: OneDrive Cloud Service Abused for Phishing

parsed_raw_data.title: OneDrive Cloud Service Abused for Phishing
parsed_raw_data.overview: Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign that is leveraging OneDrive to host their malicious content. The phishing email claims a file has been shared via OneDrive and provides a shortened OneDrive link to visit. Hosted on this OneDrive URL is a PDF containing hyperlinked text to a second-stage phishing page. If a user falls for this trick and visits the secondary page, they are presented with logon options for multiple email services combined with further OneDrive branding. Each login option provides a different fake login page; for example, one led to an Outlook login page while another presented a Box login. When a user provides credentials, the entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to a benign research article.

instruction: List mitre mitigations for CrateDepression - Rust Supply Chain Attack Targets Cloud Pipelines
output:
Here is the list of mitre att&ck mitigations for CrateDepression - Rust Supply Chain Attack Targets Cloud Pipelines: Mitigation ID: M1016
Mitigation name and Description: Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1046
Mitigation name and Description: Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Profero and Security Joes report on a security incident appearing to be perpetrated by APT27 or Winnti. The focus of the report is on a new backdoor named Clambling, which appears to be unique to one of these actors. Clambling seems to be a variant of the Type 2 Backdoor. The campaign began via a 3rd party compromise that led to the deployment of the ASPXSpy webshell for lateral movement. The actor uses DLL side-loading via the vulnerable Google Updater DLL to install both the PlugX and Clambling backdoors. They also mention the presence of Mimikatz and a privilege escalation exploit on the victim hosts. Clambling has an infection chain that includes creating persistence via either a system service or Registry Run key, injecting itself into legitimate processes, and establishing communication with its C2 server. Once installed, the operator can send arbitrary commands to be executed on the victim host. The researchers note one use of this backdoor access was to use Bitlocker to encrypt victim hard drives. This is significant because it could support evidence of APT27 moving from cyber espionage operations to a focus on financial gain. The other possible actor, Winnti, can be connected loosely through code and infrastructure overlaps in previous Winnti campaigns. The report does not confidently attribute the attack to either group.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Clambling Backdoor

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Symantec published a blog post analyzing a new threat actor, believed to be nation-state-backed, carrying out espionage campaigns in South Asia. The group is specifically targeting telecommunications, IT, and government organizations with a specific focus on Afghanistan. The initial infection vector is unknown but Symantec researchers identified the post-compromise infection chain. A custom downloader that leverages Microsoft Azure infrastructure for C2 communication with the ultimate purpose of installing the Graphon backdoor. This backdoor also abuses legitimate Microsoft Azure endpoints for C2 capabilities. It allows the attackers to execute Windows commands remotely. The threat group's toolset also includes a custom screenshot tool, a Cobalt Strike Beacon configured to use CloudFront infrastructure for C2, and Metasploit. Based on the toolset and observed activity, the group's motivation is espionage, and Symantec believes the group is a nation-state-backed, advanced persistent threat (APT).

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Harvester APT Targeting South Asia in Espionage Campaign

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Trend Micro has observed an attack on an insecure Docker implementation that attempts to escape privileged containers. The attack targeted a Trend Micro honeypot with insecure Docker APIs that the attackers located using the zgrab scanner. If successful, the attack could allow access to the host system. If the escape fails, an image that does not require privileges would be installed. The cryptominer process is named nginx so it appears to be a legitimate service. The attack demonstrates that attackers are becoming more sophisticated, trying more techniques, and also highlights the dangers of running containers with privileges.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Docker Targeted Using Container Escape Features

The attack demonstrates that attackers are becoming more sophisticated, trying more techniques, and also highlights the dangers of running containers with privileges.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
EST Security has published a blog post analyzing Thallium malware samples disguised as cryptocurrency wallet apps. In order to distribute their malicious code, they injected it into legitimate applications, essentially performing a supply chain attack. Two different operating systems were targeted, Windows and Android. On Windows, the code is distributed via either the wallet installer or a firmware update program. Along with the legitimate code is the threat actor's code that ensures communication is established with a C2 server. In the same way, Android APKs for legitimate wallet apps were repackaged to include the actor's code that establishes C2 communication. It was reported that unauthorized withdrawal of coins were made in some cases. Credentials were also able to be stolen by the malware. The activity has been attributed to the Thallium APT based on code overlaps, such as the use of the same mutex and string encryption method.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps

parsed_raw_data.title: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps

instruction: Can you list all mitre att&ck mitigations related to Analysis of a Quantum Ransomware Attack
output:
Certainly. Mitre att&ck mitigations related to Analysis of a Quantum Ransomware Attack are: Mitigation ID: M1015
Mitigation name and Description: Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1025
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1032
Mitigation name and Description: Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1043
Mitigation name and Description: Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1048
Mitigation name and Description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1053
Mitigation name and Description: Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The NetDooka malware framework, discovered and named by Trend Micro, contains multiple elements including a dropper, a loader, a protection driver, and a remote access Trojan (RAT). Distribution of NetDooka is being carried out by a pay-per-install service using a modular downloader named PrivateLoader that is typically delivered to victims in pirated software. PrivateLoader executes the first of the NetDooka malware, a dropper that is used to download the next stage, NetDooka's loader. The loader carries out a number of tasks including checking that it isn't running in a virtual environment, creating a new virtual desktop that it uses to uninstall a number of anti-virus products, and may also install a kernel driver. The last stage is the deployment of the RAT which also carries out a number of system checks to detect analysis environments. The RAT provides features typical of many remote access Trojans though C&C communications are carried out using a custom protocol.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: The NetDooka Malware Framework

Distribution of NetDooka is being carried out by a pay-per-install service using a modular downloader named PrivateLoader that is typically delivered to victims in pirated software. PrivateLoader executes the first of the NetDooka malware, a dropper that is used to download the next stage, NetDooka's loader. The loader carries out a number of tasks including checking that it isn't running in a virtual environment, creating a new virtual desktop that it uses to uninstall a number of anti-virus products, and may also install a kernel driver. The last stage is the deployment of the RAT which also carries out a number of system checks to detect analysis environments. The RAT provides features typical of many remote access Trojans though C&C communications are carried out using a custom protocol.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Job offers are the subject of this particular phishing campaign and they carry BLINDINGCAN RAT as a payload, a SentinelOne paper states. The defense and aerospace industries in Europe and the United States are the primary targets of this campaign. An infected system in a key location can provide the attackers with valuable intelligence and key technologies, the article indicated. The attachment attempts to exploit CVE-2017-0199, a vulnerability in the processing of RTF files, which can result in the execution of arbitrary code if successful. Once infected, the malware contacts its command and control servers for additional components, such as a keylogger and clipboard monitor. Information about the system is sent back to the command and control servers.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: North Korea Distributing BLINDINGCAN RAT

instruction: Give me mitre mitigations for CopperStealer Malware Distributed in Fake Cracks
output:
Mitre att&ck mitigations for CopperStealer Malware Distributed in Fake Cracks: Mitigation ID: M1013
Mitigation name and Description:Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  


Mitigation ID: M1015
Mitigation name and Description:Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  


Mitigation ID: M1016
Mitigation name and Description:Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  


Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description:User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  


Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description:User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  


Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1024
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  


Mitigation ID: M1025

Mitigation ID: M1045

Mitigation ID: M1046

Mitigation ID: M1049

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description:Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Mitigation name and Description:Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction: List mitre mitigations for What You Must Know About a New Variant of Lorenz Ransomware
output:
Here is the list of mitre att&ck mitigations for What You Must Know About a New Variant of Lorenz Ransomware: Mitigation ID: M1013
Mitigation name and Description: Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1032
Mitigation name and Description: Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1048
Mitigation name and Description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1053
Mitigation name and Description: Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description: Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Yicai Global announced in an article that charging stations in China may have been compromised by hackers. Users are warned to take caution when using such public charging stations. When necessary, using your own cable that is known to not be configured to transfer data, is your best option, if possible.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
From Alert (AA21-042A)  
Compromise of U.S. Water Treatment Facility

On February 5, 2021, unidentified cyber actors obtained unauthorized access to the supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) system at a U.S. drinking water treatment plant. The unidentified actors used the SCADA system’s software to increase the amount of sodium hydroxide, also known as lye, a caustic chemical, as part of the water treatment process. Water treatment plant personnel immediately noticed the change in dosing amounts and corrected the issue before the SCADA system’s software detected the manipulation and alarmed due to the unauthorized change. As a result, the water treatment process remained unaffected and continued to operate as normal. The cyber actors likely accessed the system by exploiting cybersecurity weaknesses, including poor password security, and an outdated operating system. Early information indicates it is possible that a desktop sharing software, such as TeamViewer, may have been used to gain unauthorized access to the system. Onsite response to the incident included Pinellas County Sheriff Office (PCSO), U.S. Secret Service (USSS), and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).

The FBI, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center (MS-ISAC) have observed cyber criminals targeting and exploiting desktop sharing software and computer networks running operating systems with end of life status to gain unauthorized access to systems. Desktop sharing software, which has multiple legitimate uses—such as enabling telework, remote technical support, and file transfers—can also be exploited through malicious actors’ use of social engineering tactics and other illicit measures. Windows 7 will become more susceptible to exploitation due to lack of security updates and the discovery of new vulnerabilities. Microsoft and other industry professionals strongly recommend upgrading computer systems to an actively supported operating system. Continuing to use any operating system within an enterprise beyond the end of life status may provide cyber criminals access into computer systems.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: NCAS Alert AA21-042A - Compromise of U.S. Water Treatment Facility

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
NCC Group has been tracking the threat group TA505 (IBM tracks as ITG19) and has uncovered several different malicious programs related to a peer-to-peer network that communicates via UDP. In the report, the researchers provide an analysis of three tools, which are speculated to be developed by the same developers as 'Grace'. The first tool is a downloader, which runs as a service and is used to download the second stage from the command and control server. It does this by decrypting and executing a payload which, in turn, decrypts and runs a driver. The driver is used to inject the final payload into a new process (‘wmiprvse.exe’). The final payload is able to register the victim computer with the P2P network and communicate with other nodes via UDP. This has been attributed ITG19 due to similar naming conventions and programming styles to that seen in 'Grace' samples. The researchers found evidence that at least 3 separate P2P networks were running based on network IDs of the samples.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: TA505 Linked To Malicious Peer-to-Peer Networks

parsed_raw_data.title: TA505 Linked To Malicious Peer-to-Peer Networks
parsed_raw_data.overview: NCC Group has been tracking the threat group TA505 (IBM tracks as ITG19) and has uncovered several different malicious programs related to a peer-to-peer network that communicates via UDP. In the report, the researchers provide an analysis of three tools, which are speculated to be developed by the same developers as 'Grace'. The first tool is a downloader, which runs as a service and is used to download the second stage from the command and control server. It does this by decrypting and executing a payload which, in turn, decrypts and runs a driver. The driver is used to inject the final payload into a new process (‘wmiprvse.exe’). The final payload is able to register the victim computer with the P2P network and communicate with other nodes via UDP. This has been attributed ITG19 due to similar naming conventions and programming styles to that seen in 'Grace' samples. The researchers found evidence that at least 3 separate P2P networks were running based on network IDs of the samples.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
In a blog based on the research of a ransomware package called Hentai Oniichan, VMRay reports on their analysis of one of the two variants, Berserker, they found during their investigation. Berserker examines running processes in an effort to terminate any matching programs that are on its internal list. It also attempts to terminate any processes that might interfere with its encryption of files, such as backup software, monitoring software, or software that may hold files open like database applications. Information, such as user name, computer name, and client key, is sent via email to its command and control server. In addition to deleting shadow copies and disabling recovery mode, Beserker goes the extra mile by attempting to remove backup files based on a list of backup extensions. This does leave open the possibility of deleting data that cannot be restored, such as non-backup data on virtual drives. After a file is encrypted, a ".HOR" extension is added to the name. When the system has been encrypted, two types of ransom notes are delivered.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Hentai Oniichan Ransomware

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Cofense published a blog post detailing a Microsoft credential phishing campaign. The initial phishing email impersonates Power BI and claims a sales report is ready to view. It resembles a legitimate Microsoft notification and, in some cases, stolen credentials were used to increase the legitimacy of the phish. Clicking on the link provided in the email leads to a fake Microsoft login page. After submitting credentials, victims are redirected to an error message. This is done in an attempt to distract the user from the credential theft by providing reasoning for why the report could not be viewed.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Phishing Campaign Spoofing Power BI

Proofpoint Threat Research discovered a new credential phishing campaign named BadBlood, carried out by threat group TA453 (aka Charming Kitten, Phosphorous, Newscaster) in late 2020. IBM X-Force tracks the group as ITG18. The campaign targets senior medical professionals who specialize in genetic, neurology, and oncology research in the United States and Israel. These targets are not the traditional targets for TA453, however, the tactics and techniques observed in BadBlood continue to mirror those used in historic TA453 campaigns. The malicious emails contain a link to a TA453-controlled domain.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The DFIR Report has published a blog post analyzing an incident involving credentials being stolen from Laravel, an open-source PHP framework that assists with sending mail through various services. When debug mode is enabled by users on Laravel systems, the .env file becomes accessible on the web server and credentials from that file are sent in plain text in responses. One attacker took advantage of the issue by logging into a victim system as local admin over RDP. From this system, they executed a Python script capable of scanning a list of IP addresses and URLs for the presence of strings related to the Laravel credentials in responses. If matches are found, the details are saved to text files that can be viewed or exfiltrated by the attacker. The script looks for a variety of credentials including PayPal, Office365, Twilio, AWS, Mailgun, and more.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Laravel Apps Leaking Secrets

Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1055
Mitigation name and Description: Do Not Mitigate - This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description: Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Cisco Talos published a blog post analyzing recent changes to Oblique RAT and its infection chain. The first major change is in how the payload is delivered. While maldocs with macros are still used, the payload is no longer embedded in the document. Instead, the macro retrieves the payload from a compromised website. It arrives in the form of a BMP file and is either extracted directly to disk or is found within an extracted ZIP archive. After being delivered to the system, it is renamed with a ".pif" extension and persistence is established by creating a shortcut file in the user's Startup directory. In terms of changes to the RAT itself, Cisco uncovered four new versions of the malware since their last report on it. First, anti-analysis techniques were added to ensure the samples would not run in a sandbox environment. File enumeration and stealing capabilities as well as webcam/desktop screenshot capabilities and commands were added. Furthermore, one of the older versions added an unused command, indicating additional commands will likely continue to be incorporated. The most recent version only made a single change, altering the mutex name.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: ObliqueRAT Returns with New Campaign Using Hijacked Websites

It arrives in the form of a BMP file and is either extracted directly to disk or is found within an extracted ZIP archive. After being delivered to the system, it is renamed with a ".pif" extension and persistence is established by creating a shortcut file in the user's Startup directory. In terms of changes to the RAT itself, Cisco uncovered four new versions of the malware since their last report on it. First, anti-analysis techniques were added to ensure the samples would not run in a sandbox environment. File enumeration and stealing capabilities as well as webcam/desktop screenshot capabilities and commands were added. The most recent version only made a single change, altering the mutex name.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence (XFTI) believes at least one Sodinokibi affiliate is abusing Rclone, a legitimate command-line secure data transfer software, by exfiltrating a massive quantity of data from a victim’s environment to the attacker-controlled MEGA account. The researchers expect that Rclone’s abuse will increase by attackers like Sodinokibi due to its attractive capabilities, such as its ability to conduct secure data transfers, including “transfers over limited bandwidth [and/or] intermittent connections,” and sync to over 40 cloud storage services, specifically MEGA, a service preferred by Sodinokibi.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Rclone Cloud Storage Software Abused To Steal Several GBs Data

Mitigation ID: M1024
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1039
Mitigation name and Description: Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1053
Mitigation name and Description: Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Palo Alto's Unit 42 has published a report on changes to the TTPs used by TeamTNT. The group has dropped the targeting of Kubernetes and Docker APIs, are no longer exfiltrating data from infected systems, and are not using the zgrab network scanner. Instead, TeamTNT has copied techniques used by the cryptojacking group, WatchDog. Among the changes are the use of additional Monero mining pools and a directory structure used by WatchDog. According to Unit 42, this is not the first time TeamTNT has adopted the TTPs of other groups. In the past, TeamTNT utilized TTPs from the Kinsing group. Unit 42 concludes that the changes to TTPs are to allow TeamTNT to increase its cryptomining operations while attempting to hide the operations by appearing to be those of the WatchDog group.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: TeamTNT Adopt TTPs From WatchDog Group

parsed_raw_data.title: TeamTNT Adopt TTPs From WatchDog Group
parsed_raw_data.overview: Palo Alto's Unit 42 has published a report on changes to the TTPs used by TeamTNT. The group has dropped the targeting of Kubernetes and Docker APIs, are no longer exfiltrating data from infected systems, and are not using the zgrab network scanner. Instead, TeamTNT has copied techniques used by the cryptojacking group, WatchDog. Among the changes are the use of additional Monero mining pools and a directory structure used by WatchDog. According to Unit 42, this is not the first time TeamTNT has adopted the TTPs of other groups. In the past, TeamTNT utilized TTPs from the Kinsing group. Unit 42 concludes that the changes to TTPs are to allow TeamTNT to increase its cryptomining operations while attempting to hide the operations by appearing to be those of the WatchDog group.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Due to past laws in South Korea which mandated the use of ActiveX controls for government and e-commerce sites, there remains a significant number of Internet Explorer users. The Magnitude exploit kit used to target Internet Explorer has been around for many years. To take advantage of the significant number of Internet Explorer users in South Korea, its operators are buying popunder ads on adult sites and pay only for those displayed to South Korean visitors to the sites. If a visitor to the site clicks on one of the ads, they are first redirected to a page that provides a legitimate-looking ad. The next redirection takes the victim to a second domain that is hosting an obfuscated JavaScript exploit for CVE-2021-26411. The second domain is short-lived, being rotated every thirty minutes, and domains are not reused. The JavaScript exploit used is one that is publicly available but includes custom shellcode, three versions of shellcode are used depending on the version of Windows the victim is using. If the exploit is successful, another vulnerability, CVE-2020-0986, is exploited to elevate privileges, and if successful, the Magniber ransomware is then injected into another process. Unlike the high profile big game hunting ransomware, Magniber does not employ the double extortion model of exfiltrating data to publish if the ransom is not paid. A ransom note is left in each directory in which files were encrypted. The ransom note contains a .onion URL that includes a subdomain that is generated dynamically, for each victim.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The JFrog Security research team has been keeping track of open-source software repositories. They have spotted an actor deploying over 200 packages as part of a targeted attack against the azure npm scope. The attacker has deployed an automatic script to create user accounts and upload the malicious packages. The new packages are typo squatting to attack existing legitimate packages and trick users into downloading the malicious ones. The payload of these packages is an info stealing malware that runs automatically upon package installation and leaks system and network information. The information is leaked via a hardcoded domain, as well as via a DNS query to the same domain. Fortunately, as the packages were caught early, the scope was limited, with an average of 50 downloads per package.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Malicious Packages Designed To Steal PII Targets Azure Developers

The new packages are typo squatting to attack existing legitimate packages and trick users into downloading the malicious ones. The payload of these packages is an info stealing malware that runs automatically upon package installation and leaks system and network information. The information is leaked via a hardcoded domain, as well as via a DNS query to the same domain. Fortunately, as the packages were caught early, the scope was limited, with an average of 50 downloads per package.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
ESET has published their analysis of CDRThief, a new Linux malware targeting VoIP softswitches. It is an ELF binary compiled via Go and capable of infecting Linux servers running Linknat VOS2009 and VOS3000 softswitch software. Its primary functionality is to steal call detail records (CDRs) from the victim servers. When first delivered to the system, it obtains credentials from configuration files on the system. Since these configuration files are AES-encrypted, it indicates the attackers had to obtain the decryption key and algorithms to access the files. With these credentials, the malware is able to access the MySQL databases that store the CDRs. Communication with the C2 server occurs via JSON over HTTP. C2 functions include those related to updating the malware and exfiltrating system information and CDRs. SQL queries are performed by the malware to obtain system event logs, VoIP gateway details, and CDRs. The data is compressed and encrypted with a RSA-1024 key. The researchers note that no common backdoor functionality, such as shell command execution, exists. ESET was unable to identify the initial infection vector or persistence mechanism. They hypothesize access is obtained via brute-force or exploiting a vulnerability.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: CDRThief Targets Linux VoIP Softswitches

parsed_raw_data.title: CDRThief Targets Linux VoIP Softswitches

It is an ELF binary compiled via Go and capable of infecting Linux servers running Linknat VOS2009 and VOS3000 softswitch software. Its primary functionality is to steal call detail records (CDRs) from the victim servers. When first delivered to the system, it obtains credentials from configuration files on the system. Since these configuration files are AES-encrypted, it indicates the attackers had to obtain the decryption key and algorithms to access the files. With these credentials, the malware is able to access the MySQL databases that store the CDRs. Communication with the C2 server occurs via JSON over HTTP. C2 functions include those related to updating the malware and exfiltrating system information and CDRs. SQL queries are performed by the malware to obtain system event logs, VoIP gateway details, and CDRs. The data is compressed and encrypted with a RSA-1024 key. The researchers note that no common backdoor functionality, such as shell command execution, exists. ESET was unable to identify the initial infection vector or persistence mechanism. They hypothesize access is obtained via brute-force or exploiting a vulnerability.
