instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a recently discovered Magento phishing page. The page mimics a legitimate Magento admin login panel, despite having a file name masquerading as a WordPress page. The CSS structure and other elements are loaded from a remote site controlled by the attacker. The interesting aspect of this phishing page as compared to most phishing pages is that it leverages JavaScript for exfiltration instead of PHP. Specifically, an EventListener method is used to send any text entered into the login fields when the user clicks outside of the boxes, regardless of whether they hit the submit button or not. The stolen credentials are base64-encoded and sent as a parameter in a GET request to the attacker's domain.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Magento Phishing Leverages JavaScript For Exfiltration

parsed_raw_data.title: Magento Phishing Leverages JavaScript For Exfiltration
parsed_raw_data.overview: Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a recently discovered Magento phishing page. The page mimics a legitimate Magento admin login panel, despite having a file name masquerading as a WordPress page. The CSS structure and other elements are loaded from a remote site controlled by the attacker. The interesting aspect of this phishing page as compared to most phishing pages is that it leverages JavaScript for exfiltration instead of PHP. Specifically, an EventListener method is used to send any text entered into the login fields when the user clicks outside of the boxes, regardless of whether they hit the submit button or not. The stolen credentials are base64-encoded and sent as a parameter in a GET request to the attacker's domain.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
HP published a blog post analyzing a RedLine stealer campaign using a fake Windows update installer to distribute its payload. The fake site is hosted on a domain appearing to be related to Windows updates and uses content copied from the legitimate Windows 11 website. If users attempt to download the installer from this site, a ZIP file hosted on Discord is downloaded to the victim's system. Within the ZIP archive are several DLLs, an XML file, and a PE file. The PE file is padded with arbitrary data, likely to evade sandboxes and antivirus software. Upon execution, a PowerShell command is executed that spawns a cmd.exe process to perform a timeout. After this timeout, the RedLine stealer payload is downloaded from a remote server and executed. Any stolen data, such as browser credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, and credit card data, is exfiltrated back to a C2 server over TCP. The HP researchers note similarities to another RedLine stealer campaign distributing the payload via a fake Discord app installer.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: RedLine Stealer Disguised as a Windows 11 Upgrade

parsed_raw_data.title: RedLine Stealer Disguised as a Windows 11 Upgrade
parsed_raw_data.overview: HP published a blog post analyzing a RedLine stealer campaign using a fake Windows update installer to distribute its payload. The fake site is hosted on a domain appearing to be related to Windows updates and uses content copied from the legitimate Windows 11 website. If users attempt to download the installer from this site, a ZIP file hosted on Discord is downloaded to the victim's system. Within the ZIP archive are several DLLs, an XML file, and a PE file. The PE file is padded with arbitrary data, likely to evade sandboxes and antivirus software. Upon execution, a PowerShell command is executed that spawns a cmd.exe process to perform a timeout. After this timeout, the RedLine stealer payload is downloaded from a remote server and executed. Any stolen data, such as browser credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, and credit card data, is exfiltrated back to a C2 server over TCP. The HP researchers note similarities to another RedLine stealer campaign distributing the payload via a fake Discord app installer.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
CISA has issued a report on the FiveHands ransomware variant. Using publicly-available penetration testing and exploitation tools, FiveHands, and SombRAT, the threat actors were able to steal information, obfuscate files, and demand ransom from the victim. In addition to the pen testing tools, the actors used publicly-available tools to accomplish network discovery and credential access. Initially, the threat actor used a zero-day vulnerability in a VPN product to gain access to the victim network. Tools used in this attack included: SoftPerfect Network Scanner, FiveHands ransomware, PsExec.exe, ServeManager.exe, SombRAT, RoutherScan.exe, grabff.exe, rclone.exe, and s3browser-9-5-3.exe. As with most ransomware attacks, the attacker left a note behind detailing payment instructions as well as threats of continued actions against the company for non-compliance.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: FiveHands Ransomware

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
In its April 2021 security updates, Microsoft list 108 CVE numbered vulnerabilities in various Microsoft products. Of those, nineteen are rated as Critical, eighty-eight rated as Important, and one as Moderate. The most severe vulnerabilities could, if exploited, allow for remote code execution. One of the vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-28310 - a Win32k privilege escalation vulnerability, is reported to have been exploited in the wild. Six vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Chromium based browser, Edge, were addressed in a prior update. Microsoft rated these vulnerabilities as Unknown.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Microsoft Patch Tuesday - April 2021

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
RiskIQ published a blog post discussing the most recent TrickBot activity and developments. TrickBot is a Crimeware-as-a-Service malware with extensive, modular capabilities and has been used in operations by a variety of threat actors, such as TA505 and Wizard Spider, and has been observed delivering Emotet, Ryuk, Conti, and more. An attempt to take down the botnet in October 2020 temporarily slowed down the group's operations, but they have since bounced back and resumed their activity with new modules, tools, and phishing campaigns. Most recently, the group switched out their COVID-19 themed lures in exchange for traffic violation themed content. This phishing campaign claims a traffic violation has been issued and the provided link is to download the photographic evidence. The link instead downloads a ZiP archive containing a malicious JavaScript file. The JavaScript is a downloader for the TrickBot payload, which in turn can be used to spread laterally, steal credentials, and download additional payloads.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: TrickBot's Shift in Tactics

parsed_raw_data.title: TrickBot's Shift in Tactics
parsed_raw_data.overview: RiskIQ published a blog post discussing the most recent TrickBot activity and developments. TrickBot is a Crimeware-as-a-Service malware with extensive, modular capabilities and has been used in operations by a variety of threat actors, such as TA505 and Wizard Spider, and has been observed delivering Emotet, Ryuk, Conti, and more. An attempt to take down the botnet in October 2020 temporarily slowed down the group's operations, but they have since bounced back and resumed their activity with new modules, tools, and phishing campaigns. Most recently, the group switched out their COVID-19 themed lures in exchange for traffic violation themed content. This phishing campaign claims a traffic violation has been issued and the provided link is to download the photographic evidence. The link instead downloads a ZiP archive containing a malicious JavaScript file. The JavaScript is a downloader for the TrickBot payload, which in turn can be used to spread laterally, steal credentials, and download additional payloads.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Kronos, around since 2014, has undergone changes throughout its history. Now word comes about the latest upgrade to the trojan, Ares. Ares is malware with new capabilities such as information exfiltration. Ares is used in conjunction with another variant dubbed Osiris. The two malwares utilize a packer written in C++ called DarkCrypter. This version of DarkCrypter should not be confused with the commercially available packer, also called DarkCrypter. In the new variant, the first 41 strings match older Kronos variants as well as the addition of eight new strings to detect analysis tools such as sandboxes. There are, at the time of this writing, two versions of the packer. The first decrypts using Blowfish. The key size for this decryption is not the standard Blowfish size - 4 through 56 bytes vs. 288 byte fixed length. The second variant uses an embedding technique that uses a compressed format rather than Blowfish encryption. This compression algorithm is identical to Ares. The packer shows itself to be a bitmap image header. This is an obvious ruse and can be seen in photos within the article. Additionally, the actor behind the malware uses BMPack, so named by Zscaler. This packer uses an XOR-based algorithm as well as RC4. Upon decryption, the file appears as a static bitmap. Each structure within the decompressed file holds a different section of a PE file that is stitched together by a custom loader and is, subsequently, executed. Ares itself is under development as evidenced by the constant testing of new plugins and web injects. An embedded DLL module is compressed and placed within the binary. An export is loaded and used to establish persistence by creating a scheduled task that executes every two hours. Though sharing most of the code with Kronos and Osiris, there are several differences. At present, most of the samples of Ares do not communicate with a C2 over TOR. The removal of the TOR component could be used to reduce the malware size. The Ares stealer attempts to extract information from FTP clients, VPN clients, web browsers, cryptocurrency wallets applications, instant messenger clients, and email clients. Ares supports the commands as Kronos and Osiris though some commands have been modified.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Ares: Kronos Banking Trojan Evolved

There are, at the time of this writing, two versions of the packer. The first decrypts using Blowfish. The key size for this decryption is not the standard Blowfish size - 4 through 56 bytes vs. 288 byte fixed length. The second variant uses an embedding technique that uses a compressed format rather than Blowfish encryption. This compression algorithm is identical to Ares. The packer shows itself to be a bitmap image header. This is an obvious ruse and can be seen in photos within the article. Additionally, the actor behind the malware uses BMPack, so named by Zscaler. This packer uses an XOR-based algorithm as well as RC4. Upon decryption, the file appears as a static bitmap. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
UNC1151 is believed to be a state-sponsored entity involved in cyber espionage and behind at least some of the Ghostwriter activity that Mandiant first reported on in July 2020. Ghostwriter was initially a cyber influence campaign primarily targeting Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland. The campaign promoted material critical of the NATO presence in Eastern Europe. A FireEye report notes changes in the Ghostwriter operations that broadens the targeting, objectives, and TTPs. For example, in a change from the past, the campaign sought to influence Polish domestic politics. UNC1151 is also known to have targeted German politicians. The campaign uses compromised social media accounts, compromised websites, a number of domains attempting to spoof well known services, and malware distributed through spearphishing.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: UNC1151 and Ghostwriter Activity

Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1029
Mitigation name and Description: Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1032
Mitigation name and Description: Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1043
Mitigation name and Description: Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1044
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1046
Mitigation name and Description: Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1048
Mitigation name and Description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description: Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Researchers at Avast recently discovered a campaign, attributed with medium confidence to the APT group, LuckyMouse. Attribution is based on the TTPs used in previous campaigns that have been attributed to LuckyMouse. The campaign targeted East Asian government entities and the National Data Center of Mongolia. According to the researchers, backdoors and keyloggers were installed to allow extended access to the compromised networks and later used to carry out other malicious activities. LuckyMouse's toolset is extensive, utilizing common helpers, RATs and OSINT tools. Recent additions to the toolset include the Polpo and LuckyBack backdoors which were used to obtain sensitive data from the targeted government agencies. The Polpo backdoor can respond to roughly 15 different commands and has the capability to carry out the following actions: information collection and exfiltration, file transfer, and proxy connections. The LuckyBack backdoor collects certain system information and then attempts to communicate with C2 servers. It is capable of starting a remote shell, carrying out a number of operations on files, logging keystrokes, and screen capturing.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Governmental Agencies in East Asia Targeted by APT Group

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Rook ransomware, a new ransomware family based on the Babuk source code. The connection to Babuk is based on significant code overlap, such as the use of specific APIs and functions. The Babuk source code, including its builder, was leaked several times throughout 2021, which is likely how these threat actors obtained it. The payload was seen being delivered by both Cobalt Strike and via phishing campaigns. The ransomware operates similar to most families. It begins by killing processes that may interfere with encryption or are related to security products. It then deletes volume shadow copies, performs encryption, and deletes itself. No persistence mechanisms were observed during SentintelOne's analysis. The threat actors operate on a double-extortion model, threatening to release stolen data on a TOR site if the ransom is not paid. It is unknown at this time whether an affiliate model exists.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Rook Ransomware

parsed_raw_data.title: Rook Ransomware
parsed_raw_data.overview: SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Rook ransomware, a new ransomware family based on the Babuk source code. The connection to Babuk is based on significant code overlap, such as the use of specific APIs and functions. The Babuk source code, including its builder, was leaked several times throughout 2021, which is likely how these threat actors obtained it. The payload was seen being delivered by both Cobalt Strike and via phishing campaigns. The ransomware operates similar to most families. It begins by killing processes that may interfere with encryption or are related to security products. It then deletes volume shadow copies, performs encryption, and deletes itself. No persistence mechanisms were observed during SentintelOne's analysis. The threat actors operate on a double-extortion model, threatening to release stolen data on a TOR site if the ransom is not paid. It is unknown at this time whether an affiliate model exists.

instruction: Write the mitre mitigations related to Phishing Campaign Delivers Multiple Versions of Fileless Malware
output:
Sure. Here are the related mitre mitigations: Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
While investigating recent Windows privilege escalation exploits that have been attributed to Chinese actors, researchers from Check Point analyzed an exploit that had been named Jian. The exploit had previously been attributed to the Chinese group known as APT31 or Zirconium. Check Point was able to demonstrate is that Jian was actually a replica of an Equation Group exploit, EpMe. What is most interesting is that Jian was engineered by APT31 at least two years before EpMe was made public in the Shadow Brokers leak. This suggests that the 32 and 64-bit versions of EpMe were either captured in the wild while being used by the Equation Group in an operation or through an attack on Equation Group infrastructure.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Jian -  A Replica of an NSA Exploit

The exploit had previously been attributed to the Chinese group known as APT31 or Zirconium. Check Point was able to demonstrate is that Jian was actually a replica of an Equation Group exploit, EpMe. What is most interesting is that Jian was engineered by APT31 at least two years before EpMe was made public in the Shadow Brokers leak. This suggests that the 32 and 64-bit versions of EpMe were either captured in the wild while being used by the Equation Group in an operation or through an attack on Equation Group infrastructure.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A report from Sygnia indicates a connection or collaboration between Lazarus and TFlower. The TFlower ransomware is deployed using the MATA backdoor, which is a well-known Lazarus commodity. The latest variant has not previously been seen in campaigns to this point. In addition to the MATA backdoor, the threat actors behind TFlower employ MATA in order to clear forensic evidence and evade detection through identifying and tampering with security products that may be installed on the target system. The MATA backdoor consists of a three-pronged approach - an initial loader (EXE), loader (DLL), and the payload (DAT). The malware is loaded by the EXE file, which then injects the DLL into svchost.exe and also modifies the LSA security package to achieve persistence through a modified registry value. The loader then decrypts the payload stored within the DAT file, which is loaded on startup or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called. This file is loaded by lsass.exe to achieve persistence. Finally, the payload is an encrypted binary that implements backdoor functionality. C2 server addresses are encrypted within a binary configuration blob which is hard-coded within the DAT payload. More than 200 certificates and 130 IP addresses are affiliated with MATA. Analysis reveals that 95% of the functionality within the DLL match functions in the MATA framework.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: TFlower Ransomware Using MATA Framework

parsed_raw_data.title: TFlower Ransomware Using MATA Framework

The TFlower ransomware is deployed using the MATA backdoor, which is a well-known Lazarus commodity. The latest variant has not previously been seen in campaigns to this point. In addition to the MATA backdoor, the threat actors behind TFlower employ MATA in order to clear forensic evidence and evade detection through identifying and tampering with security products that may be installed on the target system. The MATA backdoor consists of a three-pronged approach - an initial loader (EXE), loader (DLL), and the payload (DAT). The malware is loaded by the EXE file, which then injects the DLL into svchost.exe and also modifies the LSA security package to achieve persistence through a modified registry value. The loader then decrypts the payload stored within the DAT file, which is loaded on startup or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called. This file is loaded by lsass.exe to achieve persistence. Finally, the payload is an encrypted binary that implements backdoor functionality. C2 server addresses are encrypted within a binary configuration blob which is hard-coded within the DAT payload. More than 200 certificates and 130 IP addresses are affiliated with MATA. Analysis reveals that 95% of the functionality within the DLL match functions in the MATA framework.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
An Iranian threat actor referred to by Microsoft as Phosphorus also has many other names associated with it, these include APT35, Ajax Security Team, Cobalt Gypsy, Operation Saffron Rose, Operation Woolen-Goldfish, Magic Hound, Newscaster, and Rocket Kitten. IBM X-Force tracks this actor as ITG18. Microsoft has attributed a phishing campaign that has targeted more than one hundred possible attendees to the Munich Security Conference and the Think 20 Summit in Saudi Arabia to Phosphorus. Emails purporting to be from the event organizers, which contained an invitation to the events, were sent to targets. If the target accepted the invitation, the campaign operators would then send a follow up email requesting information from the target. A password protected PDF file that contains a shortened link was used to lead the victim to the actual phishing page. If the victim provided credentials, the campaign operators would then use the credentials to log into the victim account, establish persistent access, and exfiltrate emails and contacts from the account.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Phosphorus Targeted Conference Attendees

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1043
Mitigation name and Description: Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1048
Mitigation name and Description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1053
Mitigation name and Description: Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description: Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Kasablanca is a threat group that is targeting 6 Bangladeshi organizations in a campaign to intercept sensitive data from either Android or Windows devices. The group was said to have deployed a new RAT in a previous campaign; however, there has been signs of that RAT being used in this campaign. The e-Gov CIRT, Bangladesh's e-Government Computer Incident Response Team, has identified several phishing sites set up for the purposes of obtaining sensitive information from the targeted organizations. The CIRT has not found a specific reason for the targeting but, as previously stated, phishing sites have been set up. The group is using the organizations as the backbone of the phishing websites. Additionally, 8 other sites have been setup using other organizations for phishing. The group's typical motives for campaign's targeting is to spread a botnet to as many computers and mobile devices as possible. The victims could be targeted due to their collection of National ID card numbers, financial information, and other information. In each instance, the targeted organizations have taken extra security measures to mitigate any current or future threats or infiltrations.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
An entry in the SANS Incident Handler's Diary reports that an HTML file attached to emails contains an obfuscated payload hidden in the ID attributes of paragraph elements. JavaScript executes when the page is loaded in a browser and it assembles the various elements into an ISO file which is then dropped onto the system. The ISO contains a copy of a Microsoft VBS file that has been modified to act as a downloader that downloads and installs a malicious DLL that has been hosted on the Discord CDN. The DLL has been obfuscated using an unregistered version of a tool named Reactor. The script also copies itself to the Startup folder to achieve persistence. The DLL is believed to be CinaRAT malware which is also known as QuasarRAT.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: CinaRAT Delivered Using HTML File Attached to Phishing Emails

JavaScript executes when the page is loaded in a browser and it assembles the various elements into an ISO file which is then dropped onto the system. The ISO contains a copy of a Microsoft VBS file that has been modified to act as a downloader that downloads and installs a malicious DLL that has been hosted on the Discord CDN. The DLL has been obfuscated using an unregistered version of a tool named Reactor. The script also copies itself to the Startup folder to achieve persistence. The DLL is believed to be CinaRAT malware which is also known as QuasarRAT.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
An extremely rare but serious vulnerability was found by GitHub on March 8 affected a small number of GitHub sessions. This comes on the heels of a March 2 incident in which anomalous traffic was observed for an authenticated user. Security and Engineering teams investigated and discovered the root cause. The company took corrective actions in terms of issuing a patch while continuing their analysis. It was determined the issued patch did indeed solve the issue and users may log in at any time. The cause of the vulnerability was a race condition in backend request handing processes that could have misrouted a user's session to an authenticated user. No accounts passwords were compromised and no SSH keys or personal access tokens (PATs) were stolen. Analysis show this condition only affected about 0.001% of authenticated sessions.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: GitHub Updates Security for Authenticated Sessions

parsed_raw_data.title: GitHub Updates Security for Authenticated Sessions

The cause of the vulnerability was a race condition in backend request handing processes that could have misrouted a user's session to an authenticated user. No accounts passwords were compromised and no SSH keys or personal access tokens (PATs) were stolen. Analysis show this condition only affected about 0.001% of authenticated sessions.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Beginning in August, the Zscaler ThreatLabZ team observed a phishing scam that attempted to install infostealing malware and obtain a victims information, in particular, their LinkedIn credentials. The scam starts with a fake recruitment company named "Jobsfinder 3EE" and a webpage featuring the LinkedIn logo. The page has two primary links, one to download a ZIP file which allegedly contains a listing of available positions, and the other to upload a CV. If the victim clinks the upload link, they are taken to a fake LinkedIn login page. Should the victim enter credentials, they will then be asked to provide their mobile number, country, and an application reference number, and of course, to upload their CV. The application reference number and details are noted as being available from the aforementioned ZIP file. In August, a password was added to the ZIP file. The ZIP file contained a binary which would install either Agent Tesla or, according to Zscaler, a previously unknown infostealer. Data from victim systems was exfiltrated using email. All the email addresses used for exfiltration and noted in the Zscaler report used the Yandex email service.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Phishing Campaign Targets LinkedIn Users with Infostealing Malware

parsed_raw_data.title: Phishing Campaign Targets LinkedIn Users with Infostealing Malware
parsed_raw_data.overview: Beginning in August, the Zscaler ThreatLabZ team observed a phishing scam that attempted to install infostealing malware and obtain a victims information, in particular, their LinkedIn credentials. The scam starts with a fake recruitment company named "Jobsfinder 3EE" and a webpage featuring the LinkedIn logo. The page has two primary links, one to download a ZIP file which allegedly contains a listing of available positions, and the other to upload a CV. If the victim clinks the upload link, they are taken to a fake LinkedIn login page. Should the victim enter credentials, they will then be asked to provide their mobile number, country, and an application reference number, and of course, to upload their CV. The application reference number and details are noted as being available from the aforementioned ZIP file. In August, a password was added to the ZIP file. The ZIP file contained a binary which would install either Agent Tesla or, according to Zscaler, a previously unknown infostealer. Data from victim systems was exfiltrated using email. All the email addresses used for exfiltration and noted in the Zscaler report used the Yandex email service.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing a recent IcedID campaign and the new evasion techniques used by the malware. The campaign involved the use of Microsoft Word documents attached to the phishing emails. Rather than including malicious code in the macro itself, the macro simply creates and executes a file based on content in the document itself. Specifically, the content is reversed, base64-encoded JavaScript that is written to an HTA file. The built-in mshta.exe is then used to execute this HTA file, which in turn executes the JavaScript code in-memory. The JavaScript code leverages PowerShell to download the IcedID payload. The use of JavaScript and PowerShell in conjunction can be used as a defense evasion technique as it may confuse certain endpoint security products. The IcedID payload itself is a DLL masquerading as a JPG. From that point the malware steal credentials, which are exfiltrated to the attacker's C2 server.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Massive IcedID Campaign with New Evasion Techniques

parsed_raw_data.title: Massive IcedID Campaign with New Evasion Techniques

The built-in mshta.exe is then used to execute this HTA file, which in turn executes the JavaScript code in-memory. The JavaScript code leverages PowerShell to download the IcedID payload. The use of JavaScript and PowerShell in conjunction can be used as a defense evasion technique as it may confuse certain endpoint security products. The IcedID payload itself is a DLL masquerading as a JPG. From that point the malware steal credentials, which are exfiltrated to the attacker's C2 server.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The eSentire Threat Response Unit conducted a recent case study on Mars Stealer malware. This malware includes the ability to collect data from browsers, and crypto-wallets. Mars Stealer has a number of capabilities that include anti-emulation and self-removal in order to obfuscate activity. It is for sale on a number of Russian-speaking forums and has attracted interest from a number of threat actors. The initial access, in this case, occurred when a victim accessed a malicious website, also known as a drive-by download. Indications are that the malware is also distributed as patching software on gaming forums.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Malware Analysis - Mars Stealer

Mitigation ID: M1031

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035

Mitigation ID: M1039
Mitigation name and Description: Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1046
Mitigation name and Description: Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A FireEye report looks at the tradecraft of a threat cluster they refer to as UNC2198 who have targeted organizations located in North America across a variety of industry sectors. The report notes that UNC2198 is the most prominent threat cluster they track that uses IcedID as their foothold in intrusions. UNC2198 are known to have obtained initial access to some systems from other groups such as UNC2420. Throughout 2020, UNC2198 were using the Maze ransomware, but around October or November began using Egregor. Once UNC2198 has a foothold in a system, other malware and tools such as Cobalt Strike, InnoSetup, Koadic, Metasploit Meterpreter, PowerShell Empire, SystemBC, and WINDARC, may be installed. Lateral movement between systems is known to have been carried out using RDP and Windows Remote Management.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: UNC2198 and IcedID

parsed_raw_data.title: UNC2198 and IcedID
parsed_raw_data.overview: A FireEye report looks at the tradecraft of a threat cluster they refer to as UNC2198 who have targeted organizations located in North America across a variety of industry sectors. The report notes that UNC2198 is the most prominent threat cluster they track that uses IcedID as their foothold in intrusions. UNC2198 are known to have obtained initial access to some systems from other groups such as UNC2420. Throughout 2020, UNC2198 were using the Maze ransomware, but around October or November began using Egregor. Once UNC2198 has a foothold in a system, other malware and tools such as Cobalt Strike, InnoSetup, Koadic, Metasploit Meterpreter, PowerShell Empire, SystemBC, and WINDARC, may be installed. Lateral movement between systems is known to have been carried out using RDP and Windows Remote Management.

Here is the list of mitre att&ck mitigations for Chinese Threat Group Using Security Software To Load Malware: Mitigation ID: M1013
Mitigation name and Description: Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1024
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1044
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Researchers from Sonatype have uncovered fake npm Roblox API packages being used to install malware and ransomware. Through the use of open source ecosystems, threat actors are able to deploy ransomware using PyPl, npm, and Rubygems. Noblox.js uses open-source JavaScript API for the creation of in-game scripts. At present, Noblox.js-proxy and Noblox.js-proxies have seen 387 total downloads of these malicious, typosquatted packages. The typosquats lead to Noblox's README page. The page appears normal but contains a section of obfuscated code that installs postinstall.js. This drops a Batch script that, in turn, is used to contact a C2 server for the download of the final payload, trojans and ransomware named Monster Ransomware. Attribution to DarkDev or DarkDev1 has been made at this point.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware

parsed_raw_data.title: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware
parsed_raw_data.overview: Researchers from Sonatype have uncovered fake npm Roblox API packages being used to install malware and ransomware. Through the use of open source ecosystems, threat actors are able to deploy ransomware using PyPl, npm, and Rubygems. Noblox.js uses open-source JavaScript API for the creation of in-game scripts. At present, Noblox.js-proxy and Noblox.js-proxies have seen 387 total downloads of these malicious, typosquatted packages. The typosquats lead to Noblox's README page. The page appears normal but contains a section of obfuscated code that installs postinstall.js. This drops a Batch script that, in turn, is used to contact a C2 server for the download of the final payload, trojans and ransomware named Monster Ransomware. Attribution to DarkDev or DarkDev1 has been made at this point.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
## ***UPDATE February 3, 2021***

SonicWall has announced a firmware update, 10.2.0.5-29sv, to patch the previously reported zero-day vulnerability on SMA 100 series 10.x code. All users are encouraged to immediately apply the patch to avoid exploitation. 

Devices requiring the critical patch include:

  * Physical Appliances: SMA 200, SMA 210, SMA 400, SMA 410
  * Virtual Appliances: SMA 500v (Azure, AWS, ESXi, HyperV)



## ***Original Collection***

A coordinated attack on SonicWall's internal systems led to the identification of a vulnerability in its SMA 100 series products. The threat actors were most likely exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities. Impacted products include Secure Mobile Access version 10.x running on SMA 200, SMA 210, SMA 400, SMA 410 physical appliances, and the SMA 500v virtual appliance. Products not affected include SonicWall Firewalls, NetExtender VPN Client, SMA 1000 series, and SonicWall SonicWave APs. The vulnerability has a CVSS v3 score of 8.8 making it high risk for affected systems. No details were provided with regard to any type of nefarious action taken by the highly sophisticated threat actor. A workaround can be found here: <https://www.sonicwall.com/support/product-notification/210122173415410>.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: URGENT: Probable Zero-Day SMA 100 Vulnerability

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
F-Secure researchers attempting to exploit the Samsung S20 device discovered a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application. This vulnerability existed in the store's use of a WebView activity with a JavaScript interface. The WebView activity targeted by the researchers, "com.sec.android.app.samsungapps.slotpage.EditorialActivity," can be launched via a browsable intent link or NFC tag and would allow for the download or opening of an application from the Galaxy Store based on a provided package name. The vulnerability specifically results from the allowance of HTTP URLs which, in turn, results in plaintext traffic. If an attacker had control of a WiFi network and can convince a victim to scan a custom NFC tag with their device, they could intercept the traffic associated with this activity to inject malicious JavaScript and force the phone to install and launch an application of the attacker's choice from the Galaxy Store. An update to the Galaxy Store app, version 4.5.20.7, provides a fix for this by only allowing HTTPS URLs to be used in conjunction with this WebView activity.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Samsung S20 - RCE via Samsung Galaxy Store App

parsed_raw_data.title: Samsung S20 - RCE via Samsung Galaxy Store App
parsed_raw_data.overview: F-Secure researchers attempting to exploit the Samsung S20 device discovered a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application. This vulnerability existed in the store's use of a WebView activity with a JavaScript interface. The WebView activity targeted by the researchers, "com.sec.android.app.samsungapps.slotpage.EditorialActivity," can be launched via a browsable intent link or NFC tag and would allow for the download or opening of an application from the Galaxy Store based on a provided package name. The vulnerability specifically results from the allowance of HTTP URLs which, in turn, results in plaintext traffic. If an attacker had control of a WiFi network and can convince a victim to scan a custom NFC tag with their device, they could intercept the traffic associated with this activity to inject malicious JavaScript and force the phone to install and launch an application of the attacker's choice from the Galaxy Store. An update to the Galaxy Store app, version 4.5.20.7, provides a fix for this by only allowing HTTPS URLs to be used in conjunction with this WebView activity.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar SIEM, 6427025, has been published. QRadar SIEM uses Google Protocol Buffers. The version of Google Protocol Buffers distributed with QRadar SIEM contains a vulnerability (CVE-2015-5237), caused by an integer overflow in MessageLite::SerializeToString. The vulnerability could potentially allow a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition or execute arbitrary code.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Vulnerability May Allow Arbitrary Code Execution in IBM QRadar SIEM

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
In part one of a six part series, Google's Project Zero details some vulnerabilities found as part of a "make 0-day hard" goal. Part one focuses on the discovery of a watering hole attack in 2020. This attack, it is hypothesized, was carried out by a highly sophisticated threat actor. In the attack, two exploit servers were delivering exploit chains via this watering hole attack. One server was targeting Windows users and the other, Android users. Interestingly, both used Chrome exploits for remote code execution. Both used 0-day vulnerabilities. The Android exploit was known to the researchers. The researchers believe the actor had access to Android 0-days but discovered no new vulnerabilities. The researchers also discovered two sandbox escape exploits abusing three 0-day vulnerabilities within Windows. Another discovery was that of a privilege escalation kit composed of publicly known n-day exploits which can be employed against older versions of Android. Efficiency and flexibility are seemingly the order of the day for these exploit chains. In future parts of the series, the team will provide detailed analysis of the vulnerabilities, exploit techniques, deep dive into the bug class of the Chrome exploits, and an in-depth teardown of the post-exploitation code for Android.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Google's Project Zero In The Wild Series

Interestingly, both used Chrome exploits for remote code execution. Both used 0-day vulnerabilities. The Android exploit was known to the researchers. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The NetWire RAT has been around some eighteen years since the first versions were discovered. Versions of NetWire can be purchased on underground forums with prices ranging from $40 to $140 dollars, according to a Proofpoint report. Proofpoint has been tracking campaigns targeting a range of industries in Bulgaria since late 2019. The more recent iterations of these campaigns used a low volume of emails and targeted a limited number of companies spread across a number of industry sectors. The emails typically purported to be from Bulgarian government departments. In a couple of campaigns it was the Sofia Court House, and in the most recent, it was the Commission for Combating Corruption and Confiscation of Illegally Acquired Property. The lures used in the recent emails are typically that some form of legal action has been initiated against the recipient. The campaigns have some common features: the language used in the emails and documents is Bulgarian, the malicious Word documents used were authored by "vps", the C&C domain, and the NetWire RAT payload and config password. When one of the malicious documents is opened and macros are enabled, certutil is used to download the NetWire payload. However, the payload is only downloaded and executed if the victim's IP address is located in Bulgaria. NetWire itself is a multi-platform RAT that provides features typical of many RATs. Persistence is achieved through setting a Registry Run key.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Bulgarian Companies Targeted in Spear-Phishing Campaigns Delivering NetWire

Proofpoint has been tracking campaigns targeting a range of industries in Bulgaria since late 2019. The more recent iterations of these campaigns used a low volume of emails and targeted a limited number of companies spread across a number of industry sectors. The emails typically purported to be from Bulgarian government departments. In a couple of campaigns it was the Sofia Court House, and in the most recent, it was the Commission for Combating Corruption and Confiscation of Illegally Acquired Property. The lures used in the recent emails are typically that some form of legal action has been initiated against the recipient. The campaigns have some common features: the language used in the emails and documents is Bulgarian, the malicious Word documents used were authored by "vps", the C&C domain, and the NetWire RAT payload and config password. When one of the malicious documents is opened and macros are enabled, certutil is used to download the NetWire payload. However, the payload is only downloaded and executed if the victim's IP address is located in Bulgaria. NetWire itself is a multi-platform RAT that provides features typical of many RATs. Persistence is achieved through setting a Registry Run key.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Sophos has published their analysis of the most recent version of Lemon_Duck. The first change the researchers noticed was the use of COVID-19-themed emails to social engineer users. Attached to these emails is an Office document that leverages an RTF exploit for CVE-2017-8570 to install the malware. Once an initial foothold is gained, the malware contains code necessary to construct new emails and attachments on-the-fly that are then sent to recipients in the victim's contact list in order to compromise additional networks. For infection of and lateral movement to Windows hosts, Lemon_Duck contains exploit code for SMBGhost and EternalBlue, as well as Mimikatz. Alternatively, when infecting Linux hosts either SSH brute-force attacks are performed or Redis or Hadoop weaknesses are exploited. Cron jobs are used for persistence on Linux hosts. Lemon_Duck identifies and kills any other mining processes to maximize the resources available to its own cryptominer. Once running on the system, Lemon_Duck can perform its ultimate goal of mining cryptocurrency to turn a profit for its operators.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Lemon_Duck Cryptominer Targets Cloud Apps and Linux

The first change the researchers noticed was the use of COVID-19-themed emails to social engineer users. Attached to these emails is an Office document that leverages an RTF exploit for CVE-2017-8570 to install the malware. Once an initial foothold is gained, the malware contains code necessary to construct new emails and attachments on-the-fly that are then sent to recipients in the victim's contact list in order to compromise additional networks. For infection of and lateral movement to Windows hosts, Lemon_Duck contains exploit code for SMBGhost and EternalBlue, as well as Mimikatz. Alternatively, when infecting Linux hosts either SSH brute-force attacks are performed or Redis or Hadoop weaknesses are exploited. Cron jobs are used for persistence on Linux hosts. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Using intimidation tactics, threat actors are sending phishing emails containing information about termination of employment in order to implant malware into unsuspecting users' computer systems and networks. Initial infection is accomplished through said phishing email, which contains a Google document link, presumably, from the TrickBot gang. This link leads to the Bazar backdoor as well as the Buer loader. Trickbot has previously used different botnets, including Emotet, for the carrying out of its mission. Unlike most phishing emails, this contains no attachments, only a link to the aforementioned Google documents links. The body of the email states the recipient has been terminated and a link to the termination reasoning is included. In one such email, the reason for termination was positional redundancy. The link actually redirects to a URL used to download the malware payload. Most of the cases analyzed were instances where Bazar malware was downloaded; however, in some cases Buer loader was used. The packer for both is identical. The packed binaries contain an export function that is responsible for decryption and injection. First, a shell is deployed to decrypt a leaderless PE loader which contains the final payload. Using memory allocation, the payload is mapped into memory, given permissions, and transfers control. No self-injection is used. The Bazar backdoor is new malware and is part of TrickBot's toolkit. This is reserved for almost exclusively high profile targets. The Bazar loader is used to download and execute the backdoor, which, in turn, is used to execute binaries, scripts, modules, kill processes, and self removal. Control flow is obfuscated to hinder analysis. The Bazar loader is used to download the backdoor from a C2 using a URI format. This download was captured and analyzed. As with other Trickbot certificates, the certificates for Bazar were created in the same manner. It was also seen that the backdoor downloaded and executed the Cobalt Strike pentesting and post-exploit toolkit. It is hypothesized this is done so ransomware could be deployed, data stolen, or network access could be sold. Buer loader is sold on Russian underground forums. Most of its strings are encrypted and APIs are loaded by hash.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Buer and Bazar Malware Being Delivered in Phishing Campaign

This link leads to the Bazar backdoor as well as the Buer loader. Trickbot has previously used different botnets, including Emotet, for the carrying out of its mission. Unlike most phishing emails, this contains no attachments, only a link to the aforementioned Google documents links. The body of the email states the recipient has been terminated and a link to the termination reasoning is included. In one such email, the reason for termination was positional redundancy. The link actually redirects to a URL used to download the malware payload. Most of the cases analyzed were instances where Bazar malware was downloaded; however, in some cases Buer loader was used. The packer for both is identical. The packed binaries contain an export function that is responsible for decryption and injection. First, a shell is deployed to decrypt a leaderless PE loader which contains the final payload. Using memory allocation, the payload is mapped into memory, given permissions, and transfers control. Mitigation name and Description: Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1029
Mitigation name and Description: Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1039
Mitigation name and Description: Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1053
Mitigation name and Description: Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Google has released an update, version 85.0.4183.102, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for twenty security issues. Five CVE-numbered vulnerabilities are addressed in the update, all of which are rated by Google as High. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is insufficient policy enforcement in the installer and networking.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Chrome Browser Updates Stable Channel

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Saraburi Hospital suffered a ransomware attack, which, so far, has not resulted in a ransom demand. Dr Anant Kamolnet, director of Saraburi Hospital in Muang district of Saraburi province, said that the "computer system crashed due to a ransomware attack." Patients frequenting the hospital have been advised to bring "welfare cards, copies of referrals, ID cards, medicinal allergy cards, old prescriptions and drugs for reference if visiting the hospital." This lends credibility to the encryption of hospital files. There were initial reports of a 200,000 (about 63 billion baht) Bitcoin demand though that has been debunked by the hospital management.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Bangkok Hospital Suffers Ransomware Attack

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Avast has been tracking a large campaign that uses fake cracked software to distribute infostealer malware. The fake cracked software is distributed on compromised sites that will appear on the first page of search engines. If one of these links is clicked, the victim is redirected through a network of domains before ending up on the malicious landing page. The malware is downloaded as an encrypted ZIP file with a simple password to prevent analysis. The ZIP file contains the infostealer as an executable file. Samples analyzed by researchers show standard infostealing capabilities, the malware is able to collect user information, such as passwords, payment data, and crypto wallet information. Data is exfiltrated as an encrypted ZIP file to a hardcoded C2 address. It can also change crypto wallet addresses and reroute transactions to attacker-owned wallets.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: FakeCrack Campaign Infecting Users With Infostealer Malware

parsed_raw_data.title: FakeCrack Campaign Infecting Users With Infostealer Malware
parsed_raw_data.overview: Avast has been tracking a large campaign that uses fake cracked software to distribute infostealer malware. The fake cracked software is distributed on compromised sites that will appear on the first page of search engines. If one of these links is clicked, the victim is redirected through a network of domains before ending up on the malicious landing page. The malware is downloaded as an encrypted ZIP file with a simple password to prevent analysis. The ZIP file contains the infostealer as an executable file. Samples analyzed by researchers show standard infostealing capabilities, the malware is able to collect user information, such as passwords, payment data, and crypto wallet information. Data is exfiltrated as an encrypted ZIP file to a hardcoded C2 address. It can also change crypto wallet addresses and reroute transactions to attacker-owned wallets.

instruction: Can you list all mitre att&ck mitigations related to FFDroider Stealer Masquerading As Telegram To Avoid Detection
output:
Certainly. Mitre att&ck mitigations related to FFDroider Stealer Masquerading As Telegram To Avoid Detection are: Mitigation ID: M1015
Mitigation name and Description: Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1025
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1043
Mitigation name and Description: Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1048
Mitigation name and Description: Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1050
Mitigation name and Description: Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description: Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Researchers from DomainTools were able to identify new infrastructure used by Cloud Atlas, an APT, also known as Inception. A pattern of infrastructure creation used by Cloud Atlas shows that they have a reliance on European hosting providers such as Hostkey and OVH. The domains use consistent naming themes that include terms such as "office," update," or "ms," which are likely designed to spoof Microsoft-related items. When researchers discovered documents associated with the discovered infrastructure, they were further convinced of linking it to Cloud Atlas by the appearance of the same long numerical template string across the documents as they have previously used. The documents are Microsoft word documents, likely deployed as attachments in emails, and execute code that attempt to download additional payload files that are later called upon by powershell or vbscript.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Threat Actor Group Cloud Atlas Tracked by DomainTools Researchers

parsed_raw_data.title: Threat Actor Group Cloud Atlas Tracked by DomainTools Researchers

The domains use consistent naming themes that include terms such as "office," update," or "ms," which are likely designed to spoof Microsoft-related items. When researchers discovered documents associated with the discovered infrastructure, they were further convinced of linking it to Cloud Atlas by the appearance of the same long numerical template string across the documents as they have previously used. The documents are Microsoft word documents, likely deployed as attachments in emails, and execute code that attempt to download additional payload files that are later called upon by powershell or vbscript.
