instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A phishing campaign is using tax invoice-themed emails to deliver the Remcos RAT to Korean users according to a report from AhnLab. Attached to the email is an archive named Tax.gz which contains a single file named Tax.com. If the user executes Tax.com and if the system is 64bit it downloads the payload directly. If the system is 32bit, it downloads a PowerShell script that carries out a number of operations including downloading a DLL file that is loaded using hijacking to bypass UAC and elevate privileges. AhnLab's report provides a detailed analysis of this operation. Ultimately, the Remcos RAT payload is delivered.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Fake Tax Invoice Phishing Email Distributing Remcos RAT in Korea

parsed_raw_data.title: Fake Tax Invoice Phishing Email Distributing Remcos RAT in Korea
parsed_raw_data.overview: A phishing campaign is using tax invoice-themed emails to deliver the Remcos RAT to Korean users according to a report from AhnLab. Attached to the email is an archive named Tax.gz which contains a single file named Tax.com. If the user executes Tax.com and if the system is 64bit it downloads the payload directly. If the system is 32bit, it downloads a PowerShell script that carries out a number of operations including downloading a DLL file that is loaded using hijacking to bypass UAC and elevate privileges. AhnLab's report provides a detailed analysis of this operation. Ultimately, the Remcos RAT payload is delivered.

instruction: Can you list all mitre att&ck mitigations related to FakeCrack Campaign Infecting Users With Infostealer Malware
output:
Certainly. Mitre att&ck mitigations related to FakeCrack Campaign Infecting Users With Infostealer Malware are: Mitigation ID: M1015
Mitigation name and Description:Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  


Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description:User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  


Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description:User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  


Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description:Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  


Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description:Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description:Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  


Mitigation ID: M1029
Mitigation name and Description:Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  


Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description:Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  


Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description:Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  


Mitigation ID: M1035
Mitigation name and Description:Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  


Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description:Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  


Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description:Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  


Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description:Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  


Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description:Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  


Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description:Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  


Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description:Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  


Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description:Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  


Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description:Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  


Mitigation ID: M1051
Mitigation name and Description:Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  


Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description:User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  


Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description:Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  


Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description:Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  


Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description:Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction: List mitre mitigations for GOLDBACKDOOR Discovered in Spear-Phishing Campaign
output:
Here is the list of mitre att&ck mitigations for GOLDBACKDOOR Discovered in Spear-Phishing Campaign: Mitigation ID: M1013
Mitigation name and Description: Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1017
Mitigation name and Description: User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1018
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1021
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1022
Mitigation name and Description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description: Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1027
Mitigation name and Description: Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description: Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description: Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description: Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1032
Mitigation name and Description: Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description: Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description: Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description: Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1040
Mitigation name and Description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1041
Mitigation name and Description: Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description: Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1047
Mitigation name and Description: Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description: Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1052
Mitigation name and Description: User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1054
Mitigation name and Description: Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description: Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1057
Mitigation name and Description: Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A campaign that began in late 2021 and targets the users of eight Malaysian banks has been analyzed by ESET. The campaign uses copycat versions of legitimate sites, six of which are sites that offer cleaning services with a seventh that is a pet store. The copycat sites do not provide the ability to shop on them. Instead, they offer the download of a fake Android app that is purported to be the online shopping app from the legitimate site. The app is not downloaded from Google's Play store which means that a user would have to have enabled the "Install unknown apps" setting to allow the Android device to install the app. The app asks for a single permission, to read SMS messages. On the first run, the app asks the victim to login in but does no checks and will accept any credentials and report them as correct. The apps are themed to resemble the sites they claim to be from and allow the victim to select services and products. When the victim attempts to pay, they are offered the choice of paying using one of eight Malaysian banks or a credit card. ESET notes in its report that the credit card option was not selectable during their testing. Bank details entered into the app are sent to the campaign operators and the app reports to the user their credentials were rejected. All SMS messages received on the infected device are forwarded to the campaign operators. This provides the operators with any SMS messages used for Two-Factor Authentication.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Malaysian Bank Customers Targeted

On the first run, the app asks the victim to login in but does no checks and will accept any credentials and report them as correct. The apps are themed to resemble the sites they claim to be from and allow the victim to select services and products. When the victim attempts to pay, they are offered the choice of paying using one of eight Malaysian banks or a credit card. ESET notes in its report that the credit card option was not selectable during their testing. Bank details entered into the app are sent to the campaign operators and the app reports to the user their credentials were rejected. All SMS messages received on the infected device are forwarded to the campaign operators. This provides the operators with any SMS messages used for Two-Factor Authentication.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The key findings from ESET's long-running investigation into Latin American banking Trojans have been published in an article that is the conclusion of the series. Twelve Trojans have been covered in the series. The most targeted Latin American countries are Brazil and Mexico. More recently Spain has become a target with two Trojans, Grandoreiro and Mekotio, being used in attacks. Over the course of the investigation, three of the Trojans went dormant with at least eight remaining active. One discovery made by ESET is that while the various Trojans are the product of independent actors, there is a significant amount of communication between the authors. This is demonstrated by code similarities and changes to techniques occurring across the range of Trojans within short time frames of each other. One area where there is far less commonality is in the fake pop-up windows used to capture the victim's data. These seem to be independent with each family of Trojans having their own pop-ups, even when targeting the same bank. The great majority of campaigns involving the banking Trojans use spam to distribute them and each campaign typically lasts around a week. Typically, the emails have a ZIP file or an MSI installer attached. Another feature common to many of the Trojans is that when a system becomes infected, certain data about the system is sent to a registration server which is separate from the C&C servers.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Latin American Banking Trojans

One discovery made by ESET is that while the various Trojans are the product of independent actors, there is a significant amount of communication between the authors. This is demonstrated by code similarities and changes to techniques occurring across the range of Trojans within short time frames of each other. One area where there is far less commonality is in the fake pop-up windows used to capture the victim's data. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
VMRay has published a blog post analyzing Ave_Maria and a packer it leveraged for obfuscation. The infection chain begins with the packer, which is a .NET binary. It starts by establishing persistence via a scheduled task that executes at logon. A new process is created in a suspended state. Ave_Maria is then extracted and decoded from the packer's resource section and unpacked into the new process. The Ave_Maria payload is comprised of two executables. The first one is the stealer payload which performs the majority of the malicious activity. It establishes a secondary method of persistence by writing itself to a Registry Run key. The stealer payload also performs the main purpose of the malware, stealing credentials from various applications, such as browsers and email clients. The second executable that is injected into memory is simply a UAC bypass that leverages DLL hijacking.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Ave_Maria and Packer Malware Analysis

parsed_raw_data.title: Ave_Maria and Packer Malware Analysis
parsed_raw_data.overview: VMRay has published a blog post analyzing Ave_Maria and a packer it leveraged for obfuscation. The infection chain begins with the packer, which is a .NET binary. It starts by establishing persistence via a scheduled task that executes at logon. A new process is created in a suspended state. Ave_Maria is then extracted and decoded from the packer's resource section and unpacked into the new process. The Ave_Maria payload is comprised of two executables. The first one is the stealer payload which performs the majority of the malicious activity. It establishes a secondary method of persistence by writing itself to a Registry Run key. The stealer payload also performs the main purpose of the malware, stealing credentials from various applications, such as browsers and email clients. The second executable that is injected into memory is simply a UAC bypass that leverages DLL hijacking.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
A remotely exploitable code execution vulnerability (CVE-2022-22954) in VMware Workspace ONE Access is being exploited to deploy a backdoor, according to a report from Morphisec. On successful exploitation, a PowerShell stager is deployed which in turn downloads a PowerShell loader named PowerTrash. The loader decompresses the final payload, a Core Impact Agent, and reflectively loads it into memory. This technique leaves no forensic evidence on the disk.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: VMware Workspace ONE Access Exploited to Deploy New Backdoor

parsed_raw_data.title: VMware Workspace ONE Access Exploited to Deploy New Backdoor
parsed_raw_data.overview: A remotely exploitable code execution vulnerability (CVE-2022-22954) in VMware Workspace ONE Access is being exploited to deploy a backdoor, according to a report from Morphisec. On successful exploitation, a PowerShell stager is deployed which in turn downloads a PowerShell loader named PowerTrash. The loader decompresses the final payload, a Core Impact Agent, and reflectively loads it into memory. This technique leaves no forensic evidence on the disk.

instruction: Can you list all mitre att&ck mitigations related to Malaysian Bank Customers Targeted
output:
Certainly. Mitre att&ck mitigations related to Malaysian Bank Customers Targeted are: Mitigation ID: M1001
Mitigation name and Description: Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1005
Mitigation name and Description: Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1006
Mitigation name and Description: Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1011
Mitigation name and Description: User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 

Mitigation ID: M1012
Mitigation name and Description: Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Sucuri researchers are resorting to exfiltrating stolen credit card numbers using image files. A hacked Magento site led the researchers to the discovery of a severe infiltration of MageCart tools. The site had an old, vulnerable version of Magento as its front end. The version had its support sunset as well as having several of the formerly available security updates taken offline. Researchers found two image files populated with base64 data. Upon decoding, the analysts found plain text credit card numbers, cvv numbers, billing addresses, expiration dates, and other information. Using core file integrity checks, the analysts were able to identify files with non-matching hashes. Unlike many javascript malware, this was not seen during browser loading or via external scan. As with other MageCart infections, the files required to skim the credit card numbers must infect a file involved in the checkout process. The researchers were able to see a file being repeatedly infected, ./app/code/core/Mage/Admin/Model/Session.php. This file had a differing hash and was examined thoroughly. This file was the culprit in the attack. Using an inverse method of decoding, the file contained the arrow.gif file used to exfiltrate concatenated information. Comment chunks were used to hide the malware. A second image file was examined with the same results, a concatenated file with credit card numbers and other information.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: MageCart Using Image Files for Card Number Exfiltration

parsed_raw_data.title: MageCart Using Image Files for Card Number Exfiltration
parsed_raw_data.overview: Sucuri researchers are resorting to exfiltrating stolen credit card numbers using image files. A hacked Magento site led the researchers to the discovery of a severe infiltration of MageCart tools. The site had an old, vulnerable version of Magento as its front end. The version had its support sunset as well as having several of the formerly available security updates taken offline. Researchers found two image files populated with base64 data. Upon decoding, the analysts found plain text credit card numbers, cvv numbers, billing addresses, expiration dates, and other information. Using core file integrity checks, the analysts were able to identify files with non-matching hashes. Unlike many javascript malware, this was not seen during browser loading or via external scan. As with other MageCart infections, the files required to skim the credit card numbers must infect a file involved in the checkout process. The researchers were able to see a file being repeatedly infected, ./app/code/core/Mage/Admin/Model/Session.php. This file had a differing hash and was examined thoroughly. This file was the culprit in the attack. Using an inverse method of decoding, the file contained the arrow.gif file used to exfiltrate concatenated information. Comment chunks were used to hide the malware. A second image file was examined with the same results, a concatenated file with credit card numbers and other information.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
ASEC published a blog post analyzing an infostealer discovered targeting Korean users. The file was discovered in connected with a phishing URL targeting Kakao account credentials. Visiting the root URL as opposed to the specific phishing page leads to the download of a ZIP archive. It masquerades as a Naver OTP tool for accessing the Korean web portal. While the fake application is displayed, in the background two malicious executables are dropped. Persistence is established via LNK files in the Startup folder. One of the executables is used for gathering system information and directory listings. The other is a keylogger. Data gathered by these two payloads is staged in a folder created by the malware and exfiltrated via a POST request to a remote server.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Infostealer Disguised as Well-Known Korean Web Portal File

It masquerades as a Naver OTP tool for accessing the Korean web portal. While the fake application is displayed, in the background two malicious executables are dropped. Persistence is established via LNK files in the Startup folder. One of the executables is used for gathering system information and directory listings. The other is a keylogger. Data gathered by these two payloads is staged in a folder created by the malware and exfiltrated via a POST request to a remote server.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The Kinsing and NSPPS malwares were thought to be from two different families of malware. A report from CyberArk concludes they are both variants of the same family of malware. CyberArk believes the first version of the malware was compiled prior to November 2019, was used as a RAT and was named as NSPPS. When the malware was updated with new packages and included cryptomining functionality, it was named as Kinsing. The CyberArk report provides an analysis of the differences, and commonality between the analysed variants, to support their findings.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Kinsing and NSPPS Malwares are the Same Family

When the malware was updated with new packages and included cryptomining functionality, it was named as Kinsing. instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Different TTPs and independent infrastructure have led to Trend Micro separating an actor from under the Winnti umbrella, the actor has been named Earth Lusca. Trend's report notes that the actor has also been referred to as TAG-22 or Fishmonger in other reports. Earth Lusca is known to have targeted a diverse range of organizations and government entities including those involved in cryptocurrency trading platforms, COVID-19 research, education, gambling, the news media, pro-democracy and human rights, and religious movements. The targets have been located in various countries including Australia, China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Mongolia, Nepal, Nigeria, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, the United States, and Vietnam. To gain a foothold in a target, the group is known to have used spearphishing, watering hole websites, and the exploitation of vulnerabilities in public-facing servers. Trend believes the objective of the group's activities is cyberespionage but may also have a financial motivation. The group deploys a wide range of malware and tools in their operations including AntSword, Behinder, Cobalt Strike, Doraemon, FunnySwitch, ShadowPad, and Winnti.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Out From Under the Winnti Umbrella - Earth Lusca

Mitigation name and Description:Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  


Mitigation ID: M1024
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  


Mitigation ID: M1025
Mitigation name and Description:Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  


Mitigation ID: M1026
Mitigation name and Description:Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  


Mitigation ID: M1028
Mitigation name and Description:Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  


Mitigation ID: M1030
Mitigation name and Description:Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  


Mitigation ID: M1031
Mitigation name and Description:Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  


Mitigation ID: M1033
Mitigation name and Description:Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  


Mitigation ID: M1037
Mitigation name and Description:Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  


Mitigation ID: M1038
Mitigation name and Description:Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  


Mitigation ID: M1042
Mitigation name and Description:Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  


Mitigation ID: M1043
Mitigation name and Description:Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  


Mitigation ID: M1044
Mitigation name and Description:Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  


Mitigation ID: M1045
Mitigation name and Description:Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  


Mitigation ID: M1049
Mitigation name and Description:Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  


Mitigation ID: M1056
Mitigation name and Description:Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the techniques used in Cring ransomware infections. Initial access is obtained through either exposed RDP services or vulnerability exploits, such as those in Adobe ColdFusion and FortiGate VPN. When the threat actor has obtained access, they leverage Mimikatz to steal account credentials, which are used to move laterally via Cobalt Strike. Cobalt Strike is further leveraged to distribute batch scripts. These batch scripts are used to download, execute, and delete the Cring ransomware payload. Like many ransomware families, Cring disables services and processes, deletes backup files, and performs encryption.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Cring Ransomware Techniques

Cobalt Strike is further leveraged to distribute batch scripts. These batch scripts are used to download, execute, and delete the Cring ransomware payload. Like many ransomware families, Cring disables services and processes, deletes backup files, and performs encryption.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Kaspersky discovered a 0-day use-after-free vulnerability in the Win32k driver that can be used for privilege escalation, and a cluster of activity exploiting it. The vulnerability (CVE-2021-40449) affects multiple versions of Windows and has been addressed by Microsoft in their October 2021 Patch Tuesday bulletins. In addition to the vulnerability and exploitation, Kaspersky also discovered a new RAT associated with the activity that they have named MysterySnail RAT. The RAT provides fairly typical RAT functionality with some more unusual features such as the ability to monitor for inserted disks and can act as a proxy. Once executed, the RAT gathers some basic system information and then begins communicating with its C&C server, all communications channels are encrypted using SSL.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: MysterySnail and MysterySnail RAT

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The following statement was issued by Tower Semiconductor on September 6th, 2020 in response to a cyber security incident impacting certains systems and operations:

"Tower Semiconductor (NASDAQ/TASE: TSEM), today announced that the Company’s IT security systems identified a security incident on some of its systems as a result of a cyber event. As a preventive measure, the Company halted certain of its servers and proactively held operations in some of its manufacturing facilities, and has done so in a gradual, organized manner.

Tower has notified relevant authorities and is working closely with law enforcement organizations and with a leading team of worldwide experts, coordinated with its insurance providers, in order to recover the impacted systems as soon as possible. The Company has implemented specific measures to prevent the expansion of this event. At this point there is no assessment as to the actual effect on the Company."

Details on the nature of the attack have not been provided.

output: One such possible threat can be: Tower Semiconductor Experiences Cyber Security Incident

parsed_raw_data.title: Tower Semiconductor Experiences Cyber Security Incident
parsed_raw_data.overview:
The following statement was issued by Tower Semiconductor on September 6th, 2020 in response to a cyber security incident impacting certains systems and operations:

"Tower Semiconductor (NASDAQ/TASE: TSEM), today announced that the Company’s IT security systems identified a security incident on some of its systems as a result of a cyber event. As a preventive measure, the Company halted certain of its servers and proactively held operations in some of its manufacturing facilities, and has done so in a gradual, organized manner.

Tower has notified relevant authorities and is working closely with law enforcement organizations and with a leading team of worldwide experts, coordinated with its insurance providers, in order to recover the impacted systems as soon as possible. The Company has implemented specific measures to prevent the expansion of this event. At this point there is no assessment as to the actual effect on the Company."

Details on the nature of the attack have not been provided.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a dropper used to install additional payloads to various CMS platforms. A notable feature of the sample analyzed is the fact that it downloads additional payloads depending on the CMS in the environment. Regardless of which CMS is in use, the malware begins by changing permissions on certain system files and downloading additional code from Pastebin. It then checks for various system files that are specific to either WordPress, Joomla, Opencart, and Prestashop. After determining which platform is in use, it proceeds with its infection chain. Depending on the platform identified, even more code obtained from Pastebin is written to a text file on the system. Additional payloads are also downloaded from shellx[.]org. In the case of Joomla, the researchers observed two ZIP archives being downloaded, one containing a file uploader backdoor and the other the An0n_3xPloiTeR shell. Sucuri notes the present of Turkish language comments in the code.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Backdoor Shell Dropper Deploys CMS-Specific Malware

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Palo Alto published their findings from a threat hunting campaign against the Alexa top 10,000 websites. One of their findings was related to malicious coinminers, which were found being implemented via multiple methods. The first involved injecting Coinhive mining code directly into a compromised site. Unlike most attackers who typically configure coinminers to use a minimal amount of CPU in order to avoid detection, these actors barely throttled the mining activity, leading the battery of the victim device to be drained quickly. Another method of coinmining activity involved redirecting users from a legitimate used car website to a malicious link hosting the JSEcoin miner. Since the JSEcoin miner shut down, the scripts will run but the operators will not receive any currency. The same method of redirecting users from a legitimate commerce site to a malicious web page was used in a web skimmer attack. Redirecting users to a supposed reseller's site instead leads to website hosting a large number of obfuscated skimming code that is capable of collecting credit card numbers and exfiltrating them to the attacker.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Top Alexa Sites Infected With Malicious Coinminers and Web Skimmer

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
Cleafy published a blog post analyzing SharkBot, a new Android banking Trojan primarily targeting European banks. The malware masquerades as various legitimate applications, such as media streaming apps or data recovery tools. The researchers were unable to find samples within the Google Play Store, so the application must be side-loaded for installation. Once on the system, Accessibility Services permissions are requested persistently until the user grants access. SharkBot's primary goal is to initiate fraudulent money transfers from compromised devices. By using the Automatic Transfer Systems (ATS) technique, these transactions can be performed while bypassing multi-factor authentication. The ATS capabilities are carried out by a separate module that is downloaded after installation to evade detection. The payload, however, also has various built-in capabilities common to banking Trojans, such as the ability to read and hide SMS messages and perform overlay attacks to steal credentials. The researchers note that observed strings, the use of a demo version of an obfuscater, and unimplemented functionality implies that SharkBot may still be in development.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: SharkBot Android Trojan Targeting European Banks

parsed_raw_data.title: SharkBot Android Trojan Targeting European Banks
parsed_raw_data.overview: Cleafy published a blog post analyzing SharkBot, a new Android banking Trojan primarily targeting European banks. The malware masquerades as various legitimate applications, such as media streaming apps or data recovery tools. The researchers were unable to find samples within the Google Play Store, so the application must be side-loaded for installation. Once on the system, Accessibility Services permissions are requested persistently until the user grants access. SharkBot's primary goal is to initiate fraudulent money transfers from compromised devices. By using the Automatic Transfer Systems (ATS) technique, these transactions can be performed while bypassing multi-factor authentication. The ATS capabilities are carried out by a separate module that is downloaded after installation to evade detection. The payload, however, also has various built-in capabilities common to banking Trojans, such as the ability to read and hide SMS messages and perform overlay attacks to steal credentials. The researchers note that observed strings, the use of a demo version of an obfuscater, and unimplemented functionality implies that SharkBot may still be in development.

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The threat actor named Tortilla is a relative newcomer to the ransomware landscape known to have been operating since July 2021. A report from Cisco Talos notes that Tortilla has been experimenting with various payloads. In the case of the campaign discovered by Talos in October, Tortilla appears to be exploiting the Exchange ProxyShell vulnerabilities and deploying the China Chopper web shell and Babuk ransomware variant. Other products Tortilla has been observed attempting to exploit vulnerabilities in includes Apache Struts, Atlassian Confluence, Liferay, Oracle WebLogic Server, SolarWinds Orion, and WordPress. Most of the victims of this campaign are located in the United States. Countries with smaller numbers of infections include Brazil, Finland, Germany, Honduras, Thailand, Ukraine, and the United Kingdom. The deployment of Babuk is believed to be kicked off using the China Chopper web shell to execute the initial downloader which is either a DLL or .NET file. Both lead to a loader being downloaded and executed which in turn downloads an intermediary unpacker that is used to decrypt the Babuk payload, create and execute in suspended mode, a copy of the legitimate binary AddInProcess32.exe. The Babuk payload is injected into this process. The unpacker can also inject the payload into other processes. As is typical of ransomware, backup processes are searched for and if located are terminated, the volume shadow copy is deleted, and several steps including disabling Windows Defender's real-time monitoring, script scanning, and behavior monitoring are taken to avoid detection. Files are encrypted using AES-256-CTR with the ChaCha8 cipher and a ransom note demanding payment in Monero (XMR) equivalent to $10,000 USD is left on the system. No mention of the attacker moving laterally is contained in the Talos report.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Ransomware Threat Actor Tortilla Distributing Babuk Variant

instruction:
Given the following mitigations:
The Joker malware is capable of stealing information, and money from its victim's bank accounts, as well as being able to sign the victims up to paid services, without their consent, or knowing. An article on the Cyble blog reports that an app named "QR Scanner Free" that was available on the Google Play store until early July, infected victims with a variant of the Joker malware. At the time it was removed, it had been installed more than 500 times. The app's author used a number of techniques to avoid Google's malicious app detections. The payload files are downloaded and installed on the victim device when the app is launched.

To which threat these mitigations can be relevant for?
output: One such possible threat can be: Android QR Scanner App Distributes Joker Variant
